description: From drag +‎ net, probably based on the model of Middle English draynet, dreynett (“dragnet”), Old English dræġnet, dræġnett (“dragnet”), equivalent to dray +‎ net. Cognate with Swedish dragnät, Norwegian dragnett, from Icelandic dragnet.

entries.meaning: (fishing) A net dragged across the bottom of a body of water.
(law enforcement) Heightened efforts by law-enforcement personnel to capture suspects.

verbs.description: dragnet (third-person singular simple present dragnets, present participle dragnetting, simple past and past participle dragnetted)

entries.meaning: (fishing) To drag a net across the bottom of a body of water.
(law enforcement) To make heightened efforts to catch a suspect.
